title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before 1 January 2020?
preds: Doesn't look like they are ready again for nuclear test. Still there is a chance of conducting ICBM but less & less of that as we are coming closer to year-end.
Basically we are less than one week away, and after reading all the comments from the people I am following it seems pretty unlikely.
They haven´t done so for a long time, why should they ruin Trumps christmas party now?

The easiest option is an ICBM test, not a nuclear currently. North Korea's Kim Jong Un advances nuclear threat to US as Trump talks stall
https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/north-koreas-kim-jong-un-advances-nuclear-threat-to-us-as-trump-talks-stall And there are no real tensions at the moment.

I found an error in my simulation spreadsheet when generating a similar prediction for the US democratic candidate drop outs. As of today, the simulation gives 6.5% chance. This will decrease almost 1% per week that passes without a new test. I'll keep an eye on updating this one.

They have conducted six tests since 2006 (last one in 2017), giving a base rate of about 1 every 2 years, or one every six months, +/-. I've done a monte carlo simulation, generating 2000 55 day periods randomly distributed from January 2006 to today, and I find that 19 of 2000 (0.95%) of them would include one of the past nuclear tests. Or in other words, a randomly selected 55 day period (like the one between today and the end of the question period) has a 0.95% chance of a nuclear test occurring, as a base rate. I don't know whether there are other compelling factors to suggest a higher chance today, but I'll go with 1% for now, and maybe update to 0% early December, presuming no test between now and then.

Outside view suggests we're due for a test: They've detonated 6 bombs over 13 years, or one roughly every 2 years. The last one was in September of 2017, more than 2 years ago. However, based on analysis by @Anneinak and @Raahul_Kumar, it seems that they lack the infrastructure to continue testing at that pace. Thus, lowering estimate. Slightly extremizing crowd forecast.
Everyone is playing nice for the moment, I don't think Kim has anything to gain by provoking the US in such a dramatic fashion.
I anticipated tests of missile systems... nuclear tests will not come unless the relationship between trump and kim breaks down... highly unlikely

The other day I saw a headline that said that DPRK might be able to resurrect its old nuke test site.  The article was behind a paywall, so I gave up on it.  Has anyone read anything about that?  Did it seem credible?  Was there any suggestion about how long it would take to make it operational? @Matej, @nonplus, @PhilKaiser, @ikresnak, @michalbod, @Raisinville, @dcm, @Raahul_Kumar, @cafebedouin EDIT:  Look what I found!   https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/north-korea-capable-of-restoring-dismantled-n-731455.html Sputnik - 08th October, 2019) A nuclear test site [Punggye-ri] that North Korea destroyed last year is merely "weeks or months" away from being fully functional, should the leadership choose to restore it, South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman General Park Han-ki told lawmakers on Tuesday. . . . "Two of the four tunnels - the No. 3 and No. 4 ones - could be able to be used again after repair," Park told parliament before saying that "at least weeks or months will be necessary for their restoration," as quoted by Yonhap news Agency. The general said that no moves toward restoration have been detected at the site.
~~~~~
COMMENT:  I am basing my forecast on the last sentence:  no moves toward restoration have been detected.

https://www.npr.org/2019/07/29/746060429/despite-loss-of-faith-in-kim-jong-un-the-u-s-tries-again-for-a-nuclear-deal The United States is trying again to persuade North Korea to end its nuclear weapons program. A senior U.S. official tells NPR that U.S. diplomats are communicating with the reclusive regime. They are passing messages through North Korea's mission to the United Nations in New York. The goal is a new round of "working-level" talks between experts from the two nations. President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un agreed to make such an effort during their dramatic meeting in June at the fortified boundary between North and South Korea. But the effort has begun slowly, and a question hangs over the initiative. After multiple frustrations, U.S. strategists are asking if Kim Jong Un is capable of making the nuclear deal the Trump administration wants. It's significant if the U.S. concludes Kim can't make a deal, since the U.S. has tried so hard to appeal directly to him. President Trump has now met Kim three times, exchanged letters with him and even declared that they "fell in love." Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has visited the North Korean leader in Pyongyang. "The president still has faith" that Kim can be an effective negotiating partner, said one person closely familiar with U.S. deliberations. The person asked not to be identified, citing the sensitivity of the matter. But elsewhere within the U.S. government, there is a widespread "loss of faith." The source said U.S. strategists are baffled that the North Korean ruler has seemed unable to spur his country to keep what they see as his commitments. At a summit in Singapore in June 2018, Trump and Kim committed to "work toward" denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. But U.S. diplomats grew frustrated as they tried to realize that goal. Pompeo left an October 2018 meeting with Kim believing he would allow inspectors to see a North Korean nuclear test site. But months passed and the inspectors never entered. A second summit in Hanoi in early 2019 fell apart after Kim advanced a proposal to close one of North Korea's nuclear facilities, but resisted broader U.S. demands. The third meeting between the two leaders, at the fortified border between North and South Korea last month, produced a promise to start working-level negotiations within two to three weeks. But four weeks have passed, and talks have not begun. A senior U.S. official says North Korea has yet to name a lead negotiator. Although the workings of North Korea's government are unusually opaque, three analysts told NPR that Kim does face certain political limits. While he has no meaningful political opposition, he does want to ensure the stability of his regime. Kim Jong Un "is the decision-maker," said Jenny Town of the journal 38 North, which analyzed North Korea for the Stimson Center, a nonpartisan policy research center in Washington. "He is able to make" decisions about the nuclear program, said Town, "but it doesn't come without consequences. And I think this is a bit underappreciated that there are different constituencies within North Korea that he does also have to answer to at some point." Kim has purged the ranks of both the ruling Communist Party and the North Korean military since taking power in 2011. Yet the elites around Kim and in the military may have their own views. In recent months, North Korea's state-run press has revealed signs of disagreement with nuclear diplomacy. "There seems to be a very subtle debate going on," said Town, citing articles in North Korean press "that are really questioning the value of why are we giving away our nuclear deterrent, why are we working with these capitalists?" Other articles have pushed back, stressing "the value of diplomacy." Kim has expressed skepticism. In a speech in April, he said President Trump "continuously observes" that the two leaders are friendly. But Kim added that the U.S. is making one-sided demands and using the wrong "political calculations." Analysts say Kim's own political calculations have made it hard to give up nuclear weapons. Jean Lee, a former Associated Press correspondent who spent much time in Pyongyang, said North Korea's propaganda described the nuclear program as "the one thing that he has told his people is protecting them from a foreign invasion." Giving up the nuclear program would undermine Kim's legitimacy as a ruler, said Ken Gause, who studies the North Korean leadership for CNA, a research group based in Arlington, Va. "I think he can dismantle parts of the program," Gause said, but only in ways that are "not verifiable and not irreversible," and "probably not near as much as we would want." To accept even a partial dismantling, Kim would need concessions from the United States, such as the lifting of economic sanctions against North Korea. "Kim is not moving an iota unless the U.S. put stuff on the table," said Gause, "which means money going into the pockets of the elite because that's the people he has to satisfy." The U.S. has held out the possibility of sanctions relief, but says North Korea must irreversibly give up its weapons program first. Gause is among those who think a step-by-step agreement is still possible: First one side gives a little, then the other does. But the Trump administration opposes that incremental approach, fearing North Korea would never finish. This leaves diplomats still searching for a formula that gives the U.S. what it wants — while giving North Korea's power structure what it needs.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Bottomline for me is that as far as I know, the DPRK irreversibly damaged their nuclear test site/mountain with their last test, so they will have to build a new test site before they can do another test;  I'm unaware of this happening.

North Korea can conduct a nuclear test if the US fails to meet the demands such as recalling the country’s  nuclear plan in South Korea and the assurance that the US will not  start a nuclear strike on North Korea.

As others here have pointed out, there have been six tests since 2006. [1] For a base rate one would have to know since when they've had nuclear capability. Probably they did not wait very long with the first test. Assuming 2005 gives a base rate of 6/14=~43%. As others have pointed out, there has been a significant event since the last test: the destruction of their only known test site and the announcement of the cessation of all future tests. [2] There might be other sites of course but seems unlikely overall. [3] Activity at the test seems to have resumed as well. [4] Other people here also pointed out that tests seem unnecessary at this point from a technical perspective. That leaves bargaining of course. The inside view seems much more relevant here. Overall, I estimate 7% but this is merely an informed guess. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/24/world/asia/north-korea-shuts-nuclear-test-site.html?module=inline
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-sanctions-un/north-korea-protecting-nuclear-missiles-u-n-monitors-say-ahead-of-summit-talks-idUSKCN1PU03G
[4] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-48158880

North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests, in 2006, 2009, 2013, twice in 2016, and in 2017. While the pace of testing has sped up, North Korea has taken apart some of its nuclear sights, taken part in high level talks with the United States, and has been working to improve relations with South Korea. It is very unlikely that North Korea will take any action that will harm their standing in negotiations with South Korea or the United States. Barring any major fallout from peace talks the North Koreans have few incentives to conduct a nuclear test. http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2018/11/29/2018112901762.html
https://www.politico.com/story/2019/04/13/trump-north-korea-summit-1273711
https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2180024/north-koreas-kim-jong-un-calls-more-peace-talks-souths-moon-jae

The adverse reaction would be too great.  Kim wants sanctions relief and improved economic conditions in North Korea. A nuclear test would pull the rug out from under support for any favorable action.

At this moment it seems North Korea is still willing to negotiate with the US, even if with their recent missile test they are showing that they will drive a hard bargain. My guess is more missile tests to keep up the pressure until it becomes clear that the negotiations strategy isn't going to work.
Just a very rough base line. 6 nuclear tests in 12 years, and almost one third of the year gone.

Since 2006, North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests in 2006, 2009, 2013, 2016 (twice) and 2017 respectively. The reasons why there is no nuclear test after 2017 can be divided into two parts. First, was the suspend of further nuclear tests because its capabilities had been verified in earlier 2018 and; second, the interaction between DPRK and ROK during 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea offered possibilities to softly dismantle North Korea’s nuclear arsenal through dialogue (inter-Koreas) and meeting (Trump and Kim) The 2019 Hanoi Summit failed to reach an agreement because DPRK wanted an end to all economic sanctions, and the U.S. refused to do so.  In April 2019, Kim attendance the testing of a new type of tactical guided weapon, and that was the signal to Washington that the DPRK tactics are hardening. And by now there are no detail evidence shows what type of weapon that DPRK tested. Predication included short-range guided missile and naval cruise missile, which flies low and usually covers only a very short distance.  All the collectible information is showing that Kim did not expect sanctions relief anytime soon, but he still hopes Washington offers a deal that he could accept by the end of the year (2019).  Sources:
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-41174689
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/18/world/asia/north-korea-weapons-test.html
https://www.vox.com/2019/3/15/18267286/north-korea-nuclear-missile-threat-trump

But....China can benefit on both sides and globally by promoting North Korea on economic forums by supporting relaxation of sanctions in exchange for wider cooperation with global powers.

North Korea benefits from the Trump Administration's negotiation tactics. Never before has a US president been so accommodating or attentive. ICBM and nuclear tests are intended to frighten, intimidate, and capture attention. Doing so before January 2020 might destabilize US support for Trump, thus jeopardizing North Korea's ability to negotiate on a world stage. This could ultimately mean significant issues within North Korea, where they are struggling for food and medicine that could be easily provided by a brokered partnership with South Korea and the west. Further, China is likely to want to improve North Korea's ability to trade with other global partners as a potential longer term method of avoiding the impact of future trade wars, so they are likely to push North Korea to act calmly rather than launching tests.
Down from 7% due to passage of time.
Based on the breakdown in North Korean relations with the US and the south, I think the risk of provocations has increased.
It would mean that North Korea has given up on its encroachment policy fails
new ICBM test comes first.  after that, we'll see.

Outside view: 6 tests/13 years, 46% chance in a year: 35% until 1 Jan 2020 - April 2018: North Korea announced it would suspend further nuclear tests because its capabilities had been "verified”. Implies no further tests until new tech/political reasons surface; chance to reduce to 1 test in ~6 years (up from 3 year clusters).
- reduces outside view prob to half of 35% = 17.5% + 03 March 2019: North Korea’s Sohae Satellite Launch Facility: Normal Operations May Have Resumed. Implies a souring of relations, might undertake nuclear tests as a show of defiance; test chances contingent on another summit/round of talks between US and NK:
 + Talks happen; chances 80%:
   + talks fail; chances 55%
   - talks positive; chances 45%
 - Talks do not happen; chances 20% (and hence defiant show through nuclear test) Net prob: 17.5%*(80%*55% + 20%) = 11%
Unless the situation deteriorates badly and rapidly, any message from Kim to his vassal would be better sent by an ICBM test than by a nuclear one.

Reducing from 10% due to passage of time (-1%), and some further de-escalation (-2%): US-SK to "end large-scale military drills" (codenamed Foal Eagle & Key Resolve) [1]. Compare to 2018, when FE/KR still happened, but in reduced form [2]. Imagine A and B are in conflict, and A routinely does X, which displeases B. If A stops doing X, it gives B incentive to avoid doing things that displease A. If B does something that displeases A, then A can bring back X in retaliation --- at smaller cost than other, new retaliations. Presumably, since A used to do X frequently, lots of infrastructure/process is already in place to do X. I find 38North to be a helpful source [3,4], for instance: "In Singapore, Kim and Trump got to know each other. In Hanoi, they presented their maximum versions of demands and minimum versions of possible concessions. This is common negotiating practice [...] Following the logic of a typical negotiation, the next steps will be to reduce the demands of the other side as much as possible, and to increase one’s own concessions as little as possible. The way Donald Trump bent over backwards to avoid the impression of a bitter ending indicated that he is indeed willing to continue the bilateral talks." [1] https://www.nbcnews.com/news/military/u-s-end-large-scale-military-drills-south-korea-n978111
[2] https://thediplomat.com/2018/04/us-south-korea-kick-off-annual-military-drill-without-us-strategic-assets/
[3] https://www.38north.org/2019/03/rfrank030119/
[4] https://www.38north.org/2019/02/rcarlin021919/
Little Kim may be about to lose his bessie mate in the White House. DT would not come up with the goods, and may not be there much longer, and  Kim needs to remind everyone why he's famous.
The Pyongyang Kid, like everyone else on the planet, is winning the propaganda war against The Leader Of The Free World.  No particular reason for him to do this just yet.

Reducing from 4%. For the first time since these negotiations started, both Trump and Kim now have more to lose than to gain by not coming to a deal. Kim may be a dictator but he isn't mad. A nuclear test at this delicate moment would reverse all the progress that has been made and take negotiations back to square one. Kim wants sanctions lifted and for North Korea to be regarded as a normal country. However giving up his nuclear option is a big leap of faith for Kim - he has to believe that it's not a trick, in other words he has to trust Trump. Trump wants a diplomatic feather in his cap to prove his detractors wrong, hence his extremely kind words towards Kim, whilst at the same time walking away. He wants Kim to know that he is ready to do a deal if Kim concedes a bit more. If this deal gets done, it will be because two leaders formed a relationship and trusted each other. Whatever people think of Trump and Kim as human beings, I personally want to live in a world where countries settle their differences through talking.

My forecast was above 50% previously, so this is an adjustment downward. I don't want to read too much into Trump's talks, and it may even make a test more likely, not less, if they don't go well. However, I felt sheepish for being so far away from the consensus estimate. This is a tough one and January 1, 2020 is very far away for something like this.
No sense tweaking the nose right now.

The commander of U.S. forces in South Korea cited a “palpable” decline in tensions amid U.S.-North Korean peace talks but cautioned there’s little evidence that Kim Jong Un is willing to give up his nuclear arsenal. “Today is Day 440 since the last strategic provocation” by North Korea through a missile or nuclear test, Army General Robert Abrams told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday. That’s meant “a marked reduction in tensions” on the Korean Peninsula, he said, and a reduced risk of miscalculation.

Starting from the arbitrary date of 1 Jan 2001, NK has done 6 tests. So that's 1 every 3 years, or a 1/3 chance per year. However, the pattern is that NK does these tests in exchange for aid or other concessions from foreign countries. So if we look at what stage of this game we are currently in, it's the negotiations stage. DJT has met with Kim Jong-Un, and Kim has said he wants to meet again. He also plans to meet with Moon Jae-In regularly. Starting nuclear tests up again risks all that. I anticipate several rounds of failed negotiations / defections before it comes to nuclear tests from NK, to start the game up again. I want to give it 2% or 5%, but because I have not been keeping up with NK developments for the past few months, I increase my uncertainty to 10%.

Tensions seem to be increasing as US is now saying Korea has not been taking any concrete steps to denuclearize. It feels like this adds to instability and makes a test more likely. A year feels like a very long time, and all that needs to happen is one test, so I'm continuing to move my forecast up.

Revising down based on some thinking around the impact of Chinese trade negotiations on their commitment to denuclearize NK. I'm hesitant to go too far since (for me) the logical step after developing weapon and missile capabilities is to incrementally increase the power of the bomb.

They really have nothing to win with this. They have already showed they have this capability. Showing it another time would not improve their position. Instead it would probably create anger and weaken their negotiating position.

Why wouldn't they just bide their time and quietly enhance their capabilities? It's not like conducting a test is likely to earn them sanctions relief. I also don't see how it would help them diplomatically.
Highly likely given conquest of DJT

Affirming. No place and no reason to do it.

This is a tough one with a lot of ways it could break based on a number of different possible narratives. I am inclined to believe NK will want to conduct an occassional test to remind negotiating counterparts that they are a serious threat and need to be negotiated with as such. However, I also think there's a fair amount to gain by holding off on those tests. The other thing I find persuassive against my original belief is that this question does not include ICBM tests, which seems like a more threatening test to conduct, while maintaining the narrative that NK is not actively testing nuclear weapons. I imagine this question will ping and pong quite a bit based on news (unless there's really no major news out of NK at all). If anyone has more insight into what the current state of NK's program is, I'd be interested to know because if they're firing on all cylinders with development, I have a harder time believing they'll hold off on testing all year.
Trump has turned his back on NK because he is not getting what he wants. NK might test a nuke to give Trump second thoughts about its effect on the election.

It depends how damaged the main research facility was in the explosion last year. That they will want to, is clear: Kim sees this as a virility symbol and one way in which North Korea can square up to the US and China. That they may wish to show that the facility loss was not as catastrophic as some have said, ditto: while if they were truly sabre-rattling it is true they'd need to demo an ICBM to reach the US, but you don't need one to reach Japan or China (or their Russian border, lets not forget). 
Against this is any 'peace dividend' Kim can see with South Korea because nuclear stuff is very, very expensive. Between now and 2020 is a long time in international relations. The South may have a change of government. In 2020 the US may. Kim may feel he needs to remind everyone how important he is, if the focus shifts.

North Korean nuclear weapons tests seem a good bit less likely to me than ICBM tests.  Most assume that North Korea has atomic bombs but not Teller-Ulam style hydrogen bombs now, and having atomic weapons is the biggest component of deterrence at this point.  Testing could show problems, and as long as they are fairly confident that the bombs would work, I don't see a clear benefit to testing unless they wish to get full-blown hydrogen bombs.  It seems like delivery systems would need more testing at this point.

Updating based on the New Year's Speech. Kim's note seemed defiant, but I thought one analyst put it well when he said Kim's posture may be strategic positioning in the spat between the US & China (https://www.38north.org/2019/01/rfrank010219/). Could this mean that Kim will be "incentivized" by China to discontinue nuclear tests? I could see it going either way and need further analysis. At the end of the day, though, Kim's regime has shown a willingness to start and stop nuclear tests in response to US posturing and sanctions ('16 saw two nuclear tests and '17 saw plenty of missile tests). Were these responses to the Trump administrations hard line? If so, I think we can still expect a test this year given both parties negotiating styles. I'll revise slightly down to reflect the dovish speech and acknowledge all Kim has to gain, but I could still see plenty of scenarios where another test occurs.

Mr Kim's new year's address makes it clear he does not wish to upset the peace process with North America. 
https://www.38north.org/2019/01/rcarlin010319/
“It is the invariable stand of our Party and the government of our Republic and my firm will to establish a new bilateral relationship that meets the demand of the new era as clarified in the June 12 DPRK-US Joint Statement, build a lasting and durable peace regime and advance towards complete denuclearization.”
...Kim claimed that as evidence of the North’s commitment to the above goals:
“Accordingly, we declared at home and abroad that we would neither make and test nuclear weapons any longer nor use and proliferate them, and we have taken various practical measures.”
My sense is it would take more than a year of stalemate, inaction by NK and severe sanctions by US for the situation to re-escalate to the point of resuming tests.
There are many secondary risks, which I assess/guess at less than 5%

Like practically everybody else in charge of anything anywhere on the planet,  The Pyongyang Kid is better at this game than The Leader Of The Free World.  The latter is likely to do something impulsive and unhelpful, leaving Kim to decide how hard to push.  I think an ICBM test is likelier than a nuke, but bumping this up a bit just in case.

From 2006-2017 the North performed 6 nuclear tests. Whether you assume they only have the resources/capacity to test 1 per year or 2 per year, then the base probability would be 27% or 55%. I’m inclined to go with 55% since capabilities grow over time and they did 2 in 2016.  The New Years Day speech will provide more direction, but the new posture of the Kim regime must be considered. I’m not sure how to incorporate that. I’m inclined to take the under, given how he has acted (-3% is my best guess). We’ll see what happens tomorrow..

they've done 6 tests over the last 13 years https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea This is a fairly high base rate, averaging out to roughly one every two years. Normally I'd be a fair bit higher on the odds of this happening, but the current thaw in relations between North and South drags me down a bit. Most notably, however, it's not clear why they need to conduct another such test: the last two were successful and proved to everyone that they can successfully detonate devices with acceptably high yields. If they are to resume a WMD testing programme in the next year, I'd say they are far more likely to return to ICBM testing, possibly using the "just a satellite" excuse again, since that's the part of their programme that plausibly doesn't work so well. NB also that Punggye-ri is plausibly unusable, at least in the short term

North Korea/DPRK has conducted nuclear tests before and could do so again. It conducted its sixth nuclear test on 3 September 2017, stating it had tested a thermonuclear weapon (hydrogen bomb). Kemp, Ted (3 September 2017). "North Korea hydrogen bomb: Read the full announcement from Pyongyang". CNBC News. DPRK now has the capability. Since SEP17, it has not conducted another test because of US pressure to stop their program. It is currently in KJU's best interest to hold off on nuclear tests to gain concessions from the US and international community. At this time, there are no indicators for additional tests. Because 1JAN20 is nearly 14 months from now, chances that something happens between now and then that causes KJU to conduct additional tests to re-energize negotiations is relatively high at approximately 45%.

International Observation
On October 31, 2018, Kim Min-ki, a lawmaker in South Korea's ruling Democratic Party, stated that now defunct Punggye-ri was among other nuclear and missile test sites which had been observed by officials from South Korea's National Intelligence Service and that it was now ready for planned international inspection
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punggye-ri_Nuclear_Test_Site North Korea’s Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site: Minor Cleanup Activity
https://www.38north.org/2018/11/punggye110918/ N.Korean Nuclear Site 'Was No Longer Usable' North Korea's destruction of its Punggye-ri nuclear test site came after such a severe underground collapse that the site was in any case no longer usable, a recent study suggests. The study published in the journal Seismological Research Letters claims that an aftershock observed after North Korea's last nuclear test in September last year was due to the collapse of a void as long as 80 m created after the explosion at Punggye-ri. The test itself caused an artificial 5.7 magnitude earthquake, and the aftershock registered 4.5 on the Richter scale, causing experts to suspect a major ground collapse. Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun on Wednesday said North Korea unveiled parts of demolition of the Punggye-ri nuclear test site to the media in May, but the new study shows that the site "may have been already unusable for further nuclear tests."
http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2018/11/29/2018112901762.html At the very least it will take a year to dig a new test site. The shortest time period between one nuclear test and the next was 8 months. 3 years is typical. A test by 2020 is extremely improbable. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea

the destruction of North Korea’s only known nuclear test site. With foreign journalists watching on Thursday, the North Koreans detonated explosives to destroy tunnels and buildings at the site in the country’s remote mountains.

The question doesn't specify whether merely the claim of a test by North Korea counts, or if only tests verified by an outside government count. If it's only verified tests, then verified by whom? I wonder if the question would resolve as 'yes' if say Japan verified a test but the US said it's inconclusive. I'm going to assume that only verified tests count, and hope that outside governments are in agreement with each other. The question asks if they will conduct a 'nuclear test'. It doesn't mention the word 'bomb' or 'explosion', so does any kind of 'nuclear test' count, say an experiment in a laboratory?! I'm assuming not.
Not much chance of this.  They have established their capabilities for all to see, so little need for additional testing.
